image.altText: close up of stack with cloudy and blue sky in the background

items.synopsis: While it has some pushback in favour of other waste reduction measures the facility, alongside another, is expected to process 700,000 tonnes of rubbish per year.

title.children: Waste-to-energy plants are tourist attractions overseas, and one's about to open south of Perth

image.altText: APN: Putin Forum

items.synopsis: Alexei Navalny urged Russians to dump the country's authoritarian regime. He's just been jailed for 19 years, but the thing that keeps him awake in his bunk at night might surprise you.

title.children: Putin's biggest rival is in 'one of the worst places in the world' — this is what it's like

image.altText: woman looking down

items.synopsis: The rising costs of living are increasing pressure on some international students to make difficult choices, such as paying for rent instead of mental health appointments.

title.children: Evania cannot afford mental health care as she is paying $470 a week for a room with 'big rats' and 'cockroaches'

image.altText: People with red capes chant in the street

items.synopsis: While outrage over an ABC television crew filming a protest outside the Woodside CEO's home dominated headlines, Kathryn Diss questions whether the chaos of climate action could be more harmful than helpful.

title.children: Climate activism has dominated headlines, but has the mayhem muddied the message?

image.altText: Composite image of an Indigenous man, a man in a broad-brimmed hat and a man in a shirt and tie.

items.synopsis: After two weeks of hearings in WA's remote Pilbara, Yindjibarndi traditional owners and mining company FMG are no closer to resolving their $500 million dispute.

title.children: 'It's total new ground': Amid the red dirt of the Pilbara, a $500m dispute rages on

image.altText: A close up of a pair of hands scooping up water

items.synopsis: In the dry, dusty town of Oodnadatta in central Australia, water has not only been a precious commodity, but one that has not been safe to drink.

title.children: Residents of this remote town were missing the 'basic human right' of clean drinking water, until last month

image.altText: A woman with bleached blonde hair looks off into the distance.

items.synopsis: Suicidal, anorexic and struggling with a methamphetamine addiction, Chrissy Grieve thought the world was against her. Now, the mother-of-six is helping other vulnerable people realise they are not alone.

title.children: Chrissy Grieve's son told her if she wanted to be a grandma, she had to get clean. For her, it was a turning point

image.altText: A soccer player wearing blue and light green leans on her knees with an Australian flag in the background

items.synopsis: For 96 gruelling minutes, they tried to make history on the pitch. But for these exhausted Matildas, their race was already run.

title.children: Matildas' loss to Sweden revealed a team that had already given everything

image.altText: Jack Ziebell

items.synopsis: Kangaroos champion Jack Ziebell — who called time on his career yesterday in North Melbourne's loss to Richmond — spends the night in hospital after "unprovoked attack".

title.children: Retiring North Melbourne champion Jack Ziebell spends night in hospital after 'unprovoked attack'

image.altText: Sillouette of ski chair lifts in snowy atmosphere

items.synopsis: An investigation is underway after a ski chair lift plummeted to the ground below in the New South Wales Snowy Mountains, injuring three people.

title.children: Three injured after chair lift plunges into snow below at NSW ski resort

image.altText: Baby Harrison McLaren with dad Christopher, mum Jessica and sister Lara

items.synopsis: Harry had a condition known medically as gastroschisis — a hole in his abdominal wall.

title.children: Jessica was 20 weeks pregnant when she learned her baby's organs were growing outside his body. He's now 'close to crawling'

image.altText: A graphic with vegetables and a photo of man to the right holding cabbage leaves.

items.synopsis: Schoolyard vegetable patches south of Brisbane are growing food to feed families in nearby suburbs.

title.children: 'Grow your own, feed your own': The food paradise helping families in need

image.altText: Jean-Louis Georgelin

items.synopsis: President Emmanuel Macron pays tribute to one of France's "greatest soldiers, greatest servants," who "stone by stone, was restoring the wounded beauty" of Notre Dame.

title.children: The retired French general restoring Notre Dame has died on a hike in the Pyrenees mountains

image.altText: car with broken window in front of damaged building

items.synopsis: Civilians in Chernihiv were on their way to celebrate a religious holiday when the missile strike hit the city's central square.

title.children: 'Day of pain and loss': Child among at least seven killed in Russia strike on Ukrainian city square

image.altText: A man pumps his fist in celebration.

items.synopsis: In his first home match as Tottenham Hotspur manager, Ange Postecoglou claims victory over Manchester United and sends the Spurs crowd wild.

title.children: Cork hats and Ange chants — Fans go wild for Postecoglou as Tottenham claim victory over Manchester United

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair and glasses sits on some cushions in front of a laptop, with headphones on

items.synopsis: There may be times during their menstrual cycle when women with ADHD find it harder to plan, organise and focus their attention. And they may find their ADHD medication doesn't seem to work as well. Here are some insights into why.

title.children: Why women with ADHD may get a flare-up in symptoms at certain times of their menstrual cycle

image.altText: A woman squats next to a penguin, they face each other, the ocean is in background

items.synopsis: Release days are exhilarating but full of worry for wildlife carer Tracey Wilson. She's saying goodbye to a feathered friend who washed ashore in Victoria, thousands of kilometres from home.

title.children: After weeks of love and care, this once-starved Tawaki penguin is heading home to New Zealand

image.altText: two young women on a horse, one hanging upside with legs in splits while the other stands holding her arm

items.synopsis: Normally, seeing an 11-year-old child hanging upside down on a moving horse would be cause for alarm, but Sophie Millar's parents aren't worried.

title.children: Forget the saddle, these horse riders are making an art form out of nearly falling off

image.altText: A composite of two men looking away from the camera

items.synopsis: This is not the first time prosthetic noses have popped up on screen and caused controversies towards the Jewish community.

title.children: Bradley Cooper has been accused of 'Jewface' over his new movie — here's what that means

image.altText: A graphic containing a silhouette of a side profile of a woman's face. A road sign that says 'Palmerston' is in the background

items.synopsis: A coronial inquest into Miss Yunupiŋu's death is exploring how she felt pressure from some relatives to reunite with her abusive partner leading up to her death.

title.children: 'Men’s violence is not women’s responsibility': Inside the cycle of shame, coercion and a failing system

image.altText: three forks and their shadows on a sea green background

items.synopsis: Australians spend an average of 31 years of their lives on a diet yet we remain one of the most statistically overweight people in the world. Does anything work to shift unwanted kilos?

title.children: The word 'diet' looms over weight loss, but science now has a different answer

image.altText: Goalpost

items.synopsis: AFL boss Gillon McLachlan says last night's controversial 'behind' call in Adelaide's loss to Sydney would have been overturned if it had been reviewed, in what he called a "human mistake".

title.children: 'It would have been overturned': AFL boss says umpire got it wrong in crucial 'behind' call in Crows game

image.altText: A close-up view of a white plastic rapid antigen test for COVID-19 held by hands in blue surgical gloves.

items.synopsis: BA.2.86, which has been given the nickname 'Pirola', has only been detected in Denmark, Israel, the UK and the US.

title.children: The WHO is closely monitoring another new COVID-19 variant. Here's what we know about it

image.altText: An unidentifiable woman looks out a window, seen from behind.

items.synopsis: Blessings don't come in a much better disguise than being unexpectedly tossed into jail and separated from your three-month-old baby and other young child. That's what happened to Linda, who has now graduated from the ACT Drug and Alcohol Court's program, has her children back, and is getting on with life.

title.children: Linda's ex-partner said ice would help her postnatal depression. Now she's got her kids back, and is getting on with life

image.altText: A side head shot of a middle aged man with a silver beard and silver earring

items.synopsis: Tony Read has been to the edge and made it back, where many others have not. Once he was able to get help for his mental health, it was "life-changing" — now, he and others are calling for better resourcing for people doing it tough in regional areas.

title.children: Tony went to the edge and back — and is telling his story in the hope it helps others

image.altText: Image of thylacine yawning with colours blue, green and sany brown d added.

items.synopsis: Scientists say they can bring the extinct thylacine back from the dead within a decade, but does anybody want them to? The resounding answer to an ABC survey is "Yes".

title.children: Should the thylacine be brought back to life? Here's how you responded

image.altText: Some Indigenous people at a rodeo.

items.synopsis: As the rest of the country debates the Voice referendum, there is little to no evidence of a Yes or No campaign in this Queensland city, according to locals.

title.children: ‘Denying me my right’: Indigenous leaders call for greater education amidst Voice campaign

image.altText: A before and after shot of a social media app changing the shape of a woman's body

items.synopsis: People have been aware of photoshopped images in magazines and on social media for years, but a new study has found young women are less likely to believe that videos can also be edited.

title.children: Undetectable social media filters allowing women to change their bodies in videos

image.altText: Two logging machines have been graffitied with the words "who will fight the bushfires?"

items.synopsis: Native logging will no longer be allowed in two states from next year, and there are calls for other jurisdictions to follow suit. But some experts and industry representatives say the bans could be devastating for developing nations.

title.children: Forestry industry pushes back against mounting calls for nationwide native logging ban

image.altText: Photo of cotton in a film with sunset

items.synopsis: Cotton growers have used siphons for decades to transfer water from channels over a bank onto the crop, but a few farmers are making the switch in an effort to save water.

title.children: Why these cotton farmers are ditching their siphons and going 'bank-less'

image.altText: Flames emerge from the bottom of a rocket as it lifts off

items.synopsis: An "abnormal situation" strikes Russia's Luna-25 spacecraft as it prepares to transfer to its pre-landing orbit, according to Russia's national space agency Roskosmos.

title.children: 'Abnormal situation' strikes Russian spacecraft on mission to explore Moon's south pole

image.altText: The word 'memory' is spelled out in billowing clouds of water vapour on a gridded wall in a gallery.

items.synopsis: Mexican artist-chemist Rafael Lozano-Hemmer has created an odyssey for existential dilemmas using ‘inversive’ technology.

title.children: 'The seduction of participation': Immersive artwork co-opts audience as comment on surveillance

image.altText: Tamara Oudyn smiles, standing in stage with a choir of women dressed in denim.

items.synopsis: We seem to love making fun of the "daggy" image of the community choir — but the truth is, there's a mountain of evidence backing up how they boost our wellbeing, writes ABC News presenter Tamara Oudyn.

title.children: Why does the joy of group singing attract so much 'baggage' in Australia?
